_feedbackItems.feedback: Thanks for answering! We will check back in at the end of the Learning Moment.

_items.title: reinforcing
_items.body: Provide this type of feedback when you want to recognise excellent work and motivate others to keep up the great work
Focuses on opportunities to improve results and to develop skills further
_items.title: developmental
corrective
_items.body: When performance isn’t hitting the mark, corrective feedback identifies unsatisfactory results and recommend specific actions to improve performance

Developmental Feedback

- A collaborative conversation

- Explores actions and solutions to improve


Key Benefits

- Identifies development opportunities

- Motivates others to keep going


Example

“You are on the right track with your report, however I think you need more detail here.”

“How did you think you went in your report?”

Reinforcing Feedback

- Reinforces positive behaviours 

- Acknowledges the effort put in and the results


Key Benefits

- Reinforces great work 

- Provides an opportunity to stretch capability further


Example

“The way you helped that customer was really kind. Thanks so much for providing such a great service, it really made their day!”

Corrective Feedback

- Key messages communicated candidly

- Recommendations for improvement are clear

- Consequences are outlined


Key Benefits

- Outlines potential issues impacting performance early

- Motivates others to improve


Example

“I’ve noticed you have been handling the clothes rack incorrectly. It can impact the safety of both yourself and our customers, so I want to make sure you know the correct way to handle it.”
How often do you give constructive feedback to those around you?
How comfortable do you feel giving constructive feedback that will create challenge and growth?
How comfortable do you feel giving constructive feedback that will create challenge and growth?

When you don’t provide feedback often and don’t feel confident challenging others, your team members may feel unclear on how they are performing and what they need to do to develop. You need to invest time into giving feedback. Understand that this may involve challenging their ideas to create growth. By doing this, your team will be better placed to thrive in their work.

If you don’t provide feedback often, but are confident in challenging others, then your feedback may come across as unexpected or even harsh. This means you need to take more time discussing your feedback and asking questions to reach a shared understanding of how they are performing and the situation.

When you give feedback often but are uncomfortable challenging others, you run the risk of providing sugarcoated feedback and avoiding the difficult messages. While your relationship will be strengthened with the other person, they might struggle to understand where they need to improve (or even if there is anything for them to improve upon). When giving constructive feedback make sure your messages are clear, specific and to the point.

By frequently providing feedback and feeling confident in challenging others to promote growth, you are well positioned to give valuable feedback that hits the mark with the other person. You will also be able to build a sustainable connection and stronger trust with those around you.

_items.text:
The first step in giving feedback is to describe the other person’s actions.


For reinforcing feedback, describe what they are doing well or what you were impressed by.


For corrective feedback, describe what they are doing poorly or incorrectly.


It’s important to provide context, give specific examples, and ask questions to get their perspective on their actions too.

The next step is to describe the specific impact their actions are having, either positive or negative. 


Take time to explain why the impact is meaningful. Discuss the impact of their actions on important priorities like making or saving money, putting the customer first, and living Myer's values. Connect their actions to M-Metrics and DARE performance objectives.

The last step is to communicate the desired outcome of your conversation.


Highlight that you would like to reach a constructive outcome.


Ensure team members understand what to keep doing or do differently to achieve important priorities and objectives.


Be curious and ask lots of questions.


 If sharing corrective feedback, you must provide clear expectations on what needs to improve, how, and by when. 


Schedule a follow-up conversation to check in on progress.

_feedback.correct: Well done, that’s the right order. Did you notice how questions were asked to get a better understanding of the situation? Don’t forget to try this next time you provide feedback.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: That’s not the right order, try sorting these again and remember, first identify the actions of the other person, speak about the impact, and then discuss what the desired outcome needs to be.
_partlyCorrect.final: That’s not the right order, try sorting these again and remember, first identify the actions of the other person, speak about the impact, and then discuss what the desired outcome needs to be.

_incorrect.notFinal: That’s not the right order, try sorting these again and remember, first identify the actions of the other person, speak about the impact, and then discuss what the desired outcome needs to be.
_incorrect.final: That’s not the right order, try sorting these again and remember, first identify the actions of the other person, speak about the impact, and then discuss what the desired outcome needs to be.

_items.text: “The ticketing is in the wrong spot. Can we have a talk to work out what happened?”
“Thanks for explaining what happened. It confused a number of customers.”
“What can you do next time if you are unsure where to place the ticketing?”

_feedback.correct: Well done, that’s the right order. Did you notice how questions were asked to get a better understanding of the situation? Don’t forget to try this next time you provide feedback.

_partlyCorrect.notFinal: That’s not the right order, try sorting these again and remember, first identify the actions of the other person, speak about the impact, and then discuss what the desired outcome needs to be.
_partlyCorrect.final: That’s not the right order, try sorting these again and remember, first identify the actions of the other person, speak about the impact, and then discuss what the desired outcome needs to be.

_incorrect.notFinal: That’s not the right order, try sorting these again and remember, first identify the actions of the other person, speak about the impact, and then discuss what the desired outcome needs to be.
_incorrect.final: That’s not the right order, try sorting these again and remember, first identify the actions of the other person, speak about the impact, and then discuss what the desired outcome needs to be.

_items.text: “I noticed you exceeded on key targets in your department category report.”
“I was really impressed with the results and even shared the report with a few senior business leaders.”
“I was wondering if you would be able to share some of the things you did recently to achieve these metrics, so we can implement improvements into other department areas.”

Resistance / Denial


“I don’t know what you’re talking about. I provide great service to our customers!”


Do

- Provide sufficient examples to support your feedback

- Gauge the other person’s reasons for resistance

- Ask the recipient to reflect on the feedback and end the discussion if they are being pointlessly resistant

- Candidly discuss consequences if feedback is not addressed


Don’t

- Get angry or frustrated at their reaction

- Soften your feedback to alleviate their response

- Attack the other person’s personality based on their reaction

Shock / Anger


“I’ve been working so hard and this is the thanks I get?!”


Do

- Acknowledge that the recipient is not satisfied with the feedback

- Invite the other person to offer their opinion

- Restate examples, explain your perspective


Don’t

- Become defensive

- Moderate your feedback to alleviate their reaction 

- Attack the other person’s personality based on their reaction

Lack of Confidence, Self Pity


“I can never do anything right.”


Do

- Give the recipient time to regain composure if needed

- Highlight that this is an opportunity to improve 

- Provide examples of small steps that they can take in the right direction

- Reassure him / her that they have your support


Don’t

- Reflect the recipient’s negative reaction

- Moderate your feedback to alleviate the reaction

- Focus on the recipient’s past inability to achieve outcomes

Avoiding Responsibility


“It’s not my fault…”


Do

- Listen to the employee’s reasons and situation

- Restate the examples

- Clarify that improvement is required despite their reasons 


Don’t

- Agree with the recipient if he / she blames other people

- Change your perspective based on the reasons or excuses if they are not valid

Indifference


“Okay, whatever…”


Do

- Ask recipient to reflect on the feedback and confirm whether he/she is able to commit to actioning it

- Discuss the consequences if the recipient does not commit to improving


Don’t

- Overlook the recipient’s indifference toward the feedback

- Judge or lose patience with the other person

placeholder: Eg: Plan and practice a feedback conversation with a colleague to get better at giving constructive feedback.
title: Open Input Title

_feedback._lessConfidence: Try reviewing the Learning Moment again, practicing giving feedback with a colleague or touching base with your people leader to get further support.
_feedback._matchingConfidence: That’s great that you now feel more confident about giving feedback. Keep giving feedback everyday to challenge others to grow. Remember you can revisit this Learning Moment at any time.

title: Linked Confidence Slider Title

_items.body: Kim Scott is the Author of Radical Candor. She draws on her experience as a manager at Google to highlight how leaders are able to give great feedback by caring personally for their team while also challenging them directly.

Ellen Taaffe, a Clinical Professor of Leadership at the Kellogg School, offers lessons from her decades with companies from PepsiCo to Whirlpool about the most effective ways to give and receive feedback.
Melody Wilding explains that to give great feedback, you first need to conquer your fear of confrontation.

Use this planner next time you receive feedback. 

You can also share the planner with those that you are giving feedback too, to help them reflect and improve.
